We were very unimpressed with the atmosphere of this place.  Wooden Table sounds so warm, not so much.  Very expensive and in a strip mall.  Also, the waiter kept filling our sodas and when the bill comes.....no free refills!  Almost $30 in sodas!  Never again.

A gourmet lunch in the burbs!  Whoda thunk?

A brilliant salmon salad plus great service -- I'm a simple man and that's all I need.  My business lunch date enjoyed his meal also.  We'll be back.

Horrible experience with their customer service. They advertise as a fine dinning place but act with the mentality of a small cafe in a strip mall. I made on line reservation for dinner and got an email confirmation but when I arrived a rude person at the front desk denied my reservation and insisted to have me seated at the bar. 
 I explained to him that I make reservation to have a nice dinner in a fine dinning place at a table not a bar but he kept on his unprofessional behavior saying that I can't have a table to myself and have to sit at the bar. Also I explained that I like to experience the service before I bring business group events to restaurants but he didn't care. He pretended that he would speak to the manager and came back saying that there is nothing they can do. When I insisted to speak to the manager he claimed that the manager can't speak to me and he's the one calling the shots. 

Obviously all the basic customer care manners are violated without fear of consequences. Restaurants with such manners should never be allowed to stay in business. I have never had such experience in any fine restaurant. I would strongly recommend that this restaurant should be off the list of option if anybody is looking for a nice dinner in a decent place. They're rude and disrespectful to customers.

I recently had dinner at The Wooden Table for a friend's birthday dinner. Our server, Brad, was quick (but never hurrying) and courteous, and was not only our server, but also doubled as the bartender -- and apparently a cocktail artist! He quickly brought around our drinks, which, for me, was a perfectly crafted Whiskey Sour...the prettiest I've ever seen!

Then on to dinner! I was expecting a good meal, after reading that the chef once worked at Luca and Osterio  Marco -- and I was not disappointed by any measure! Me and my two friends each selected a different pasta dish from the many delicious sounding plates on the menu. We decided on the Roasted Pork Belly Linguine, Agnolotti with Shrimp Scampi in a Tarragon Mascarpone Sauce, and Braised Lamb Shoulder Gnochhi. Each of us portioned out our pasta and shared so we could all enjoy each of these amazing dishes. Every dish was transcendent and perfectly cooked. Though each dish wowed us, the Lamb Shoulder Gnocchi definitely stood out as the star! Meat so mouthwateringly tender in a creamy sauce that did not even hint of too much butter or salt (take THAT Olive Garden!) 

Overall, service, drinks and food were amazing and a treasured find in a suburban strip mall (albeit a more upscale one!) The only thing I wouldn't say was "perfect" was the minimalist and open dining area. The open layout and tight seating made for a fairly loud room once the restaurant was filled. And for some reason the sylvan vision in my head of "The Wooden Table" was an idyllic rustic provincial restaurant (like Potager or Duo) with a  hand carved community table tucked in a corner. Alas, my musings set me up to be disappointed. However, the service and food is so exceptional, one can completely forget about  the decor as they are transported into pasta nirvana!

We had a wonderful dinner at the Wooden Table tonight. We were immediately greeted by the very friendly owner, which made is feel very welcome. The service was superb. Our server was friendly and attentive and often took care of our needs before we could even ask (like when my son dunked his car in my husband's water glass and our server immediately brought him a new water without being asked). 

The list of homemade specialty cocktails was fun to look through, and I ordered a sage lemon drop. It was a little light on the sage, but otherwise very nice. 

For appetizers we ordered pork belly and polenta. The polenta was rich, creamy, and full of fresh herbs, and topped with a flavorful homemade tomato sauce and gooey melted mozzarella. The pork belly was a little over done, but I had an end piece which may have been over cooked. Everyone else loved it. The beans and slaw served with the pork belly felt a little out of place, but they weren't bad. 

For my main course, I ordered the lobster tortelloni and LOVED it. The homemade pasta was cooked perfectly, the lobster broth was light and decadent at the same time, and there were generously large chunks of lobster claw meet amongst the pasta. The filling was a bit mushy for my liking, but even so it was extremely flavorful and delicious.  I would most definitely order my meal again.

The rest of my group loved their meals, too. Among the other dishes, the scallops were cooked nicely, the crab cake included very large chunks of crab, the duck breast was tender and melted in your mouth, and the homemade pasta was satisfyingly rustic. I thought the venison bolognese could have used some extra glamour in its presentation, but the flavor was not lacking. My husband found it to be somewhat salty for his taste, but I thought it was perfect. 

I was a little disappointed with the dessert menu at first. After such a well planned menu, I expected a bit more creativity from the desserts. However, the execution of the desserts did not disappoint. The cheese cake was marbled chocolate and something else (caramel?), but was refreshingly not too sweet and perfectly cooked. The molten chocolate cake had an intensely rich dark chocolate flavor that tasted amazing with the vanilla gelato. 

After dinner we were offered a homemade limoncello, which was a fun and tasty surprise and a great way to cap our meal. 

Some people have commented in other reviews that they didn't like the location. I agree that looking out at a parking lot isn't the greatest, but the trade-off for me is that it's great food close to home with ample parking. I love eating in trendier neighborhoods, but parking is always a challenge and the locations are rarely convenient. I love that this is 10 minutes from home and a 40-second walk to the door.

Overall, I loved this restaurant and will definitely go back.

Overall not too impressed with the quality of the food. I ordered the linguine and the  duck cavatelli. I  returned the linguine dish because the clams did not taste very fresh and was very chewy. The broth was kind of meh. The duck cavatelli dish I would order again as i thought it was their best pasta dish. I asked for the ravioli to replace the linguine. Good dish but nothing special. Ravioli filled with cheese with a sage brown butter drizzle. Nothing really stood out with the ravioli dish.

My wife ordered the tortelloni and the spinach salad. She really enjoyed the salad and thought the tortelloni dish was ok. I tasted the tortelloni dish and did not like it. They stuff the pasta with asparagus (puree?) and did not like the combination. The  very little lobster that was in the dish was chewy and the overall flavor of the dish was lacking.

I would give the desserts about a 2 star rating. The molten lava cake was dry and left a powdery bitter aftertaste. I've had much better at chain restaurants. They charge $8 for that??   At first I really enjoyed the tres leches cake until i got to the middle of it. The middle and edge of the cake was dry and not moist. I could see the cake being one of the better desserts if it is done right. The ice cream is good but it's not really a scoop of ice cream--more like a spoonful. Pretty skimpy on the ice cream proportions.

Overall, the servers are enthusiastic about the menu and service is good but the food quality is lacking and overpriced for what your getting. I would be back for the  duck cavatelli and maybe give the tres leches cake another chance. The cake has to be done right for the high price. I would give the service about 4 stars and the food about 2.5 stars.

Just a fantastic dining experience. We came down from denver and were impressed on all fronts; service food and wine paring. Shared five courses which we would recommend as you would want to try most. We will return with friends and get Robert's help as sommelier.
Food was excellent, atmosphere is nice! Service was ok, waitress was not super personable until our meal was over.

One of the BEST restaurants we have been to in a very long time!

The food was superb. Perfectly seasoned, well balanced, and great wine pairings. We tried the mussels as an app, I had the Lobster with Tagliattele (WOW!), my wife had the beef, and we split the Makers Mark peach pie with vanilla bean ice cream. The server David was well-versed on the entire menu and provided first class service. The cocktails were plentiful and well made. The GM was a true gentlemen, referring to my wife as 'Mrs. Atencio'. The attention to detail was spot on, and the food was that much better!

Thanks to you all at The Wooden Table, we have found our new favorite restaurant and we WILL be back!

~ The Atencios

This place is a solid 4 stars. I love the decor. It feels like a little Bistro. We went during Restaurant week but we would definitely be back. The food was a tad salty to me but everything was still good.

Really vacillating between a 3 and 4 star review for the Wooden Table.  The food was definitely up to snuff, and on that basis alone it should be a favorable review, but there were just enough things to detract from the experience that I have to take it down a notch.

First, the food.  Wooden Table has an excellent selection of pastas, salads, and entrees and while nothing is particularly innovative or original, they've clearly got a talented chef.  The pastas in particular are fresh-made, and I tried one of the new items on the menu, a pork belly Amatriciana.   It was excellent, very porky, with two thick pork belly slices over the fresh spaghetti tossed in a pancetta based tomato sauce. I was however expecting something a bit spicier to live up to the Amatriciana name.  For my entree, I had the duck, which was a breast served over crunchy croutons and a split pea base.  It was interesting but I didn't especially like the pea puree paired with the duck.  One niggling issue was that the menu item said that the duck was both breast and confit, but there was no confit, as far as I could tell.  I even checked the menu again afterward, to see if the confit was part of a sauce or shredded and I just missed it, but no, it was supposed to be a leg confit.  Oh well.  My wife had the scallops and they were three fat scallops nicely seared and served over a crab cake.  Others in my party had a halibut served in a brodo.   They all looked excellent and got good reports, but I didn't taste them.  

Service was nice and friendly, but it was mostly young servers.  Complimentary limoncello and amaretto were offered as after-dinner drinks, which was a nice touch.   

Now for the detractions.  First, the prices are pretty steep for a suburban strip mall.  The entrees are all mid-$20s and up, and if you really are going to get three courses as the menu seems to suggest you should do, it would easily be a 50 dollar per person bill (excluding drinks).  Even the pasta half-portions were 15 bucks or so, which as a second course is steep.   The food quality probably justifies the prices, but it can be a surprise for someone looking for more economical options.  Maybe all the Cherry Hills crowd can afford dropping $100 per couple for dinner, but for most of us it's a reach to pay that much when the next place over is a Pancake House.   Second, the location and ambience of the place feels pretty suburban strip mall; there's something cheap and Pottery Barn to the decor, maybe it's the cheap lighting.  The bathroom door is very close to some of the tables, and the size of the restaurant is so small, everyone can see when you make your way to the toilet.  It certainly is not going to impress a date.     

Finally, I also found it odd that the namesake wooden table in the middle of the restaurant never had anyone sitting at it.  We came in late for dinner, so I thought maybe that they would offer us the community table to liven up the place, but they didn't.  It sat empty the whole night.   So the wooden table is really a dead space in the middle of the restaurant surrounded by the all the other tables of eaters.  Kind of defeats the purpose, doesn't it?

Ate here this evening and we were pleasantly surprised. We went based on Yelp and Trip Advisor reviews. Not only was the food superb but the service provided by Jordan was exquisite. The variety of ingredients was unusual for what is essentially an Italian themed restaurant.  Rabbit, duck, venison, lamb and lobster to mention a few. We went on a Monday and were lucky to get in without a reservation. 
We are from the NYC area and The Wooden Table is in the league with the best from that area

Real food at a real restaurant with real service. Possibly the best Italian in the state. Eat all over the country and I can say the chefs have their formula of excellence down pat here. A little pricey but not bad, and definitely worth it.

Really great service! The manager was awesome and accommodated us without a reservation. He even provided us with complementary Prosecco. The food was fantastic - something I couldn't make at home which I really enjoyed.

Nice find in a suburban strip mall.   Been wanting to try this place for a while and a groupon gave us the impetus.  Dinner was great - from a nice, upscale ambiance to a at tentative and personable waitress (Lizzy), everything worked.  The chicken liver crostini, pumpkin pasta, and duck breast were all excellently prepared.  Will definitely be back.  Our new favorite northern italian restaurant.

I suppose there is something to be said about a persons tastes and desires. We all know that I am a fan of most everything Frank B has done in Denver. So, when I went to the Wooden Table and found out that that the driving force behind this gem is Brett Shaheen who's resume includes Chef d' Cuisine Luca d' Italia  and Executive Chef at Osteria Marco I knew I was in for a treat. 
I had been wanting to try this place for a while and finally got there for lunch date. I did my pre-dining scouting on their website and of course the menus. I am a huge fan of sweetbreads and I noticed that they had them on their dinner appetizer menu. They indulged my sweetbread fetish by allowing me to request this item off the dinner menu. Awesomeness!
The salad and sandwiches were packed with flavor and definetely not lacking in portion size.
Now to get back for dinner! Highly recommended

I went because I decided to get a Groupon.  So excited to take my  dad and his wife to lunch.   Oh no I cannot use it at lunch. Should have read the small print.  Now what do I do  with the Groupon because I really do not care to go back. We all ended up with sausage sandwiches and they were ok but I have had better.  Service was slow but the wait staff was nice.  I know better than to purchase coupons I might not use.  Instead of saving money I lost money..

Food quality: 5 stars
Service: 4 stars
Menu selection/creativity: 3 stars
Wine list: 2 stars
Atmosphere: 2 stars
Well prepared foods, but sort of a boring menu. The service was good. The wine list was heavy on chards/SB blends and medium body Italians. Their menu deserves a good Syrah or a Zin option. The atmosphere is very loud, cold and not intimate.  A few simple changes would make this a better option in an area that is under served with fine dining options.

Outstanding food and service.  We have been meaning to try this restaurant, and saw it on Groupon so we gave it a shot.  From the drinks to appetizer to entrée to dessert, everything was AMAZING.   I had their scallops and my husband has the duck-  both were 'lick your plate' good.   I would definitely recommend for a nice date night.

We had dinner here last night. The food was outstanding - the service not-so-much. Being the seasoned Yelper, I did my homework and read the reviews. We forged ahead. The place is small and loud but comfortable. We had reservations and were seated as soon as a table was available. We were told that our waiter Ramon would be with us shortly and shared that he is an expert at the wine list. Turns out that's all he was interested in. Once we passed on ordering wine - he lost the love. We had to ask for several items more than once and when the check came he hovered until a credit card appeared and snatched it up like a hawk. 

We'll be back for the yummy food. We'll just make sure our reservations are for another section. I had the ravioli and it was spectacular! My sister had the mussels and she really liked them. This place is a gem in the burbs - just steer clear of the wine expert!

My boss randomly said one day "let's go to lunch at Torchys" ... I had no clue what he was talking about. He's from Texas and knew exactly what to do. The tacos are great. Really great. The only bummer is the line and the lack of 'real' sodas... I prefer a diet coke (yes I know that is going to kill me one day) to the fancy stuff. 

Hands down, the fried avocado taco is my fav. mmmm... mouth is watering as I type this. i need to get back.

I live next to torchys so I go a good amount. The food is above average, and I always have a good time as the atmosphere is fun when you are with friends!

However, consistent with other reviews on here, the service is always slow, and not only when it is packed. Last Saturday I waited 40 minutes for 3 tacos when there was only about 6 people in front of me in line (that is a very short line for the Saturday crowd at torchys which often goes out the entrance). There was  only one food runner consistently delivering food, and she looked stressed out of her mind! You would think given all the feedback on Yelp they would have more people running food.

Also the bar could benefit from placing orders right after they get them, as they have forgotten tacos in my orders twice now.

Waited in line for 20+ minutes to eat some mediocre tacos that were expensive. $56 with tip for 4 tacos, 2 margaritas, and chips and queso and a side of rice. 

You can order drinks at the counter and the bar will bring them to you- how convenient I thought. No. When we received our chips and queso about 10 minutes after sitting down I asked our food runner if he could check on our margaritas. He said thats the bars job to bring them, but Ill check.  I watched him walk right past the bar and continue to run other peoples food. Ok, whatever we can wait a little longer. Received our food after about 15 minutes run by the same food runner. He said " oh you still haven't gotten your margaritas" Nope.  Basically finished our meal and still no margaritas in site. We had probably been there for at least 45 minutes.

I went up to the manager to explain situation and asked if he could take it off our bill since we were basically done eating and didn't wan't them. He took them off right away and even took a little bit extra off our check, which he didn't have to do.

I would hope with the high volume this place receives it could hone down on its service a bit more to be a little more efficient. I think I would try a bunch more places before coming back, but not ruling this place out for good.

Torchy's is one of my favorite places to go to in Texas so I was beyond thrilled to learn that Torchy's was coming to Denver. The tacos are amazing! The brushfire taco is my fav! The diablo sauce is aptly named so if you don't like spice, be careful. The sauce comes on the side so you can put on as little or as much as you like. Queso is one of my favorite foods in the world and I have been having withdrawals for the five years that I have lived in Colorado. Torchy's queso is so great and is definitely the reason I keep coming back.

The downside with this place is the staff. They are inconsistent, not helpful, not friendly, and overall do a poor job. Sometimes they have call ahead phone orders and sometimes they don't (and they are very rude when explaining this, with no rationale). I would really like to see more consistency and improvements with the staff (it would be a 5 star place if the service improved). IMO the food is worth the long line (which is a given so expect to wait), but there is no excuse for rude, unknowledgeable service. I thought it was just an issue when they first opened (totally understandable with a new restaurant), but it hasn't improved.

We had a causal celebratory dinner at Torchys this past Tuesday night since I've heard good things about this TX taco joint.  

DECOR: spacious and well-lit dining area with 2 bars and multiple flat screen for watching sports.  It's very modern and minimalistic.  

FOOD: we had the Baja shrimp, chick 'n and the Democrat tacos along with some chips and salsa.  The pickled onions in the shrimp taco definitely got some heat.  The poblano sauce was a bit intense for the spice level.  I liked the option for corn/flour tortilla.  Pretty average chips and salsa.  The Lil' nookies was very crunchy when you bite into it and then the gooey chocolate center just melts in your mouth - delightful!

SERVICE: average for counter service.  Our server did seemed unsure of our orders when she brought out the food and we had to confirm with her.

VERDICT: I've had better tacos than this in Denver!  I did like the spacious dining area, 2 bars and plenty of seating for large groups.  They need to have better signage for the Happy Hour menu.  I thought the price applies to food as well but it was just for beer.  And not all their beers listed on the HH menu are $2 as advertised.
They offer a variety of tacos and sides.  The Democratic taco is really tasty.  The queso and chips is delicious:  the queso is spicy and yummy with fresh cilantro.

A solid addition to Denver's taco scene! If the lines don't scare you away, this is a great spot to get your fix. I personally love the fried avocado taco (because, duh) but also suggest The Independent and the Mr. Pink. Disclaimer: these are not street tacos. I can eat A LOT of street tacos (like 3-5) but am crazy full after two Torchy's tacos. These are fully loaded and very filling.

Torchy's also has a bar for grabbing a drink and watching a game. With tacos, booze, and sports, this place will fit righhhhht in here in Denver.

Torchy's symbolizes a Tex-Mex cuisine straight outta Austin (right?!) and now has grown in great popularity and backing here in Colorado. With so many Texas transplants in CO, I can see the appeal of Torchy's Tacos. For me, it was an A-OK. 

FOOD: Brushfire and Democrat. I got these two based on a friend's recommendation (UT Austin fellow, Hook 'Em!) and must say that I was not as impressed as I would have liked have been. With so much hype by my friends in CO, I was hoping for something a bit different or more traditional Mexican. The meat was not as flavored as I would have hoped (where's the grill taste, smokiness, the rich meaty taste) and really was the salsa that carried the dish through. Also, where are all the vegetables and extra lime to cut through the meat taste? One lime is not sufficient! I wish the portion was smaller and the meat was more flavored to give it that umph taste that I know Mexican and Tex-Mex food can have and then I can try a larger variety. 

SERVICE: A little slower than I thought it would have been, but nothing to gripe about! 

Overall, maybe I'm used to California-Mexican food now. Maybe I'm pickier when it comes to my Mexican-American food. It wasn't bad, but I know Torchy's could deliver a better punch to such a wonderful cuisine.

Texas comes to Denver and I'm so happy about it! Torchy's is practically a Texas staple, so it is good to see bit of that in Denver! Delicious (somewhat heavy) street tacos and other Mexican yummies. Chips, guacamole, etc. lots of space to find a table and we loved sitting next to an open window. Reasonably priced too! Love!

Yum-Yum-Yum! I love Torchy's Tacos! Super reasonable and delicious tacos. This place is great for breakfast, lunch or dinner. If you like queso, you must try it at Torchy's, they add a little guac in the middle of their amazing hot queso. 

This placed gets really busy and the lines tend to be long, especially on the weekends or at lunch. If you want to opt out of waiting in line, I suggest calling your order in ahead or ordering online. When you do that you cut the long line (that is sometimes out the door) and can take the food to go or sit there and eat.

I always arrive starving and think I could even eat three tacos but two (plus some chips) are more than enough and I leave feeling stuffed. 

The line is always long, it feels like it takes forever, and the AC is on full blast but dang it Torchy's, I can't quit you. 

Pro tip: you can order delivery but it will usually take about an hour. The food holds up well though!

I've recently been on a mission to devour each and every brisket taco that comes within 50 miles of my pie hole.  Was driving by Torchy's, wasn't hungry but had to stop.  Line was short, menu looked good but I came for one thing...brisket.

I ordered and took my seat in anticipation,  and waited.   And waited.  Then waited some more. Let's get this straight, I ordered TWO tacos. TWO!!! It was a solid 25 minutes until I received them.  Waaaaaay to slow during down time at a place like this.

The food you ask?  The brisket taco came with jalapenos, shredded white cheese, cilantro and avacoado wedge.  It was a good size taco ( bigger than Fuzzys but twice the price) and it was good.  The brisket was good but a little over cooked.  But this is a good taco.

A really great combination would be if Torchy's used feta cheese like Fuzzys with the brisket or if Fuzzys used the avocado wedge like Torchy's. Which is a great touch.  I guess you can't have it all.  But one thing is for sure, the service on this day was much too slow in spite of getting me a very good taco.

My husband and I went on a Saturday at noon and only had to wait in the line for 5 minutes tops.  The wait to get the food was a different story and took about 15 minutes to get our order, but I don't  mind waiting for them to put together fresh ingredients and a tasty product.  

I ordered the Democrat which was shredded beef, cheese, onions and avocado served with a side of their homemade salsa.  I also ordered the street corn which had a nice flavor of sweet from the corn and smoky with the chipotle cream.  To top things off, I ordered a side of black retried beans which was on point.  My god, those beans were so smooth, creamy and perfectly seasoned!

My husband ordered the Democrat, Trashy Trailer Park with fried chicken and a poblano cream sauce and the Crossroads which was a beef brisket taco.  He said he'd order the Trashy Trailer Park all day next time.  

So that's a lot of food, right?   We can't possibly eat anymore, right?   WRONG.  We ended the meal with an order of Lil' Nookies.  OMG, who knew deep fried chocolate chip cookie dough rolled in corn flakes could b so good.  

All in all, it was busy, loud, vibrant and a fun place to eat.

Nothing that you haven't heard before... Torchy's Tacos is delish! You can choose corn or flour tortillas, the flour tortillas were cray soft and very tasty. The corn tortillas come two to a taco so there's no blowouts. I preferred the flour, but both were tasty. I also tried the street corn... oh my delish! It had just the right spicy, creamy, and sweet flavor! 

The restaurant is surprisingly big inside, but two bars take up a ton of space and so it can get pretty crowded for lunch. 

The drink selection is great too. They have a wide variety of sodas, lemonade, and tea. I will definitely be back!

Last weekend I took a trip to Denver, it had been a few days since I had Mexican food, which to me is a few days too many. I was craving tacos and a good marg and my friend had recommended Torchys. The tacos were pretty good, the meat was tender and the salsa's spicy. I liked that the salsa came on the side in a little cup so you were able to pour on how much you wanted. This is actually one of the first taco places that I have ever been to that had it on the side and I really enjoyed that. I had also ordered their house marg which was pretty good as well. The guac however was delicious and I am pretty picky about my guac. Overall the place was pretty good, however nothing extraordinary!

Torchy's is capitalizing on one - combining fairly fast food with a fun environment. The food is not going to blow your mind but you can get an in and out for under $9. 

You're sure to be met with a line out the door on any given day and almost any time. It's part of the mystique that draws so many people. "Oh look honey, there's a line out the door at that place."  "What is it?"  "I dunno, but let's go."

Loud music, TV's, margaritas, beer, tacos - that's a recipe for success my friends. 

The line goes pretty quick and you won't be short of people to watch while you wait for your food. 

I'll be back my friends (insert gun fire and fireworks and me jumping on a horse as I ride off into the distance).

I've been wanted to try this place for some time we were looking for somewhere to go open late so I finally got to try it I have to say I was not impressed I had the Baja shrimp taco which was totally flavourless the batter on the shrimp tasted like flour I also got the deep fried avocado didn't like that either we waited at least 20 minutes for 3 tacos

You were out of my favorite street corn, which is the only reason I came :/
Customer service was okay.
I guess I was just really disappointed with this visit.

While I definitely think Torchys is a good spot to grab a bite, I think there are plenty of others places you'd be fine visiting. 

Luckily, the line when I arrived wasn't too long. By the time I left, it was out the door..and tables were much harder to come by. 
Started with the chips and mild salsa. Chips were ok-you could tell they were made in house and fresh, but they definitely could've been warmer. I will say, I don't know what it was, but I loved the salsa. Like really loved it. Probably the best part of my meal. 

I ordered the democrat and the green chile pork-and both were just ok..I feel like the meat lacked flavor. I've had tacos where you can tell they marinade their meat and really spice it up, and it's a flavorgasm when you bite into it. These were just alright-some flavor, but not enough to be out-the-door-line good. I did like the side of salsa verde. 

If I bought anything here, I'd go back for the salsa. It was full of the flavor that the rest of my meal lacked.

My girlfriend and I consider ourselves to be taco experts, and while we can take our love a bit far, we don't think of ourselves as snobs, as much as purists. All we really need are two, small, corn tortillas, a decent filling, onions, cilantro, and a nice salsa on the side. 

We had heard about Torchy's for awhile, and finally had the opportunity to try them this past weekend:

1. As a principle, we always order chips and salsa with our meals, and we thought the chips were unusually excellent. The salsa was good, but on the hotter side, and came out in a large bowl - almost a tureen! 

2. The tacos are large. Their tortillas are equal to two "traditional" tacos, which is a good thing, but just remember that one taco is probably good for a snack, and two tacos is pretty damn filling. Or maybe chips and salsa, and one taco is a good meal. 

3. We tried the Brushfire, which looked really different with jerk chicken and mango (!!!), and it was hot and tasty. The best part of this taco, in my opinion, was the side of the Diablo salsa, which is hot, but not in a melt-your-face-off kind of way. I actually used it in all my tacos.

4. The Fried Avocado was good, but didn't blow our minds. Again, lots of filling, but a tasty combination of ingredients. 

5. The most disappointing taco was the one we thought we would love the best - the Democrat. Usually, I am all about shredded beef, but my girlfriend was disgusted to find not one, but TWO large chunks beef fat in the taco. I get that fat is savory, but not huge chunks in a taco. 

All in all, I would definitely return and try their other creations, but I think the tacos are hit or miss. What works are the extras: the Maine Root soft drinks; the portions; the space and décor; the quickness of food brought to the table; and of course, the chips and salsa :)

I really like this place! Being from Houston, this is the closest thing that Denver has to quality tacos. I would recommend ordering or calling ahead to place your order because it can get really crowded. The staff is always super helpful and nice; they know the menu well and everything on the menu is cheap! Also, you get a lot of food for the price, one taco filled me up and I eat a lot!

I really enjoyed the migas taco for breakfast and then I got a pork one for lunch and my total was $6 so your money goes pretty far there. They have a good happy hour as well so I would absolutely check this place out if you like yummy tacos!

First time coming here and it was delicious! I had just finished having a wonderful massage with Bradley at Chasing the Wind and since Torchy's was right across the street (with free parking), and I was hungry, decided to try them.

The place was vibrant and packed. There was already a line but it was moving quickly and liked the fact they had menus right at the front of the line so I was able to quickly give my order when it was my turn. They have 6 salsas to choose from so don't forget to order the one's you want at the front counter. I chose the Roja and that was yummy!

The cashier was friendly and efficient. I ordered the Green Chile Pork with a flour tortilla and The Independent with a corn tortilla.  I was given a number and sat down at a small table and my order was brought out within 5 minutes.

Both tacos were huge and freakingly delicious!! The location kept getting more and more people but it was organized chaos. They also offer margaritas, the usual sodas and tea to choose from. I like they have a roll of aluminum foil where you can take items you haven't eaten home to enjoy later.

They have a full bar and you can order by phone or online to skip the lines. All in all, a very good lunch experience at a good price!

Been here a few times now, and have always had a good meal.  The tacos vary (both in ingredients and taste), but I appreciate a place that takes chances on flavor combinations.  Sometimes you lose, but sometimes you win big in tasty new taco!

Was a little busy after they first opened, but now it has calmed down and is definitely a good spot to stop by for some tacos and drinks.

Presentation matters...

I visited this place after a Rookies game a Sunday night. While the overall appearance of restaurant looked great, the food presentation was a huge disappointment. I understand the restaurant was quite busy but that shouldn't be an excuse to just throw stuff on a plate. 

Service wasn't that friendly. Even sitting in the bar it felt that their goal was to get you out of there as soonest as possible.

Food has potential. I ordered 2 different tacos and the taste was not bad a at all but since my plate was a huge mess; it was really hard to understand what I was eating.

I've been in here a couple times now, and have been pleased on each occasion. 

On my first visit I was picking up breakfast tacos for the office. I was able to call in the order the day before and arrange a time for pick up. When I arrived at 7:15am, our agreed upon time, everything was ready. The tacos were individually wrapped in tin foil and stored in a disposable aluminum container, and they had included tons of individually packaged sauces in a bag. Everyone at the office was happy that day!

The second time, we wandered over for lunch. This bleeding heart liberal went with The Republican and the Trailer Park. Both were excellent, and my leftovers heated up well hours later. 

Staff have always been friendly, and prices are great. I will definitely be back.

@torchystacos Visited the original in Austin, TX. Had to try the new Denver location. I tried to visit on opening weekend but it was a madhouse so I left. Good choices. Tasty. It is hype. But delicious. Super busy at this location. Always a line. Young hipster crowd. Loud environment. 

Long wait in line to order. Long wait for the food. I recommend calling ahead. The people next to us had problems with their tacos, a human hair inside, and had to send them back. So there were hushed raised voices. But they got refunded.

The corn tortillas basically disintegrated and fell apart making for a messy meal. The sauce selection is good. The Diabolo sauce is yum and hot. Sweating hot.

Free parking lot. Lucky enough to find a spot despite how busy it was. They must get a lot of foot traffic due to the great location on Broadway. 

Overall a good place. Comparable fare to local businesses founded in Colorado. I am glad I came. You'll be glad you did as well. Try it.

Service was not so good here and either was the food. 55 minutes - the wait time for my takeout order of two tacos and a side of rice and beans.  I double checked my receipt in case I overestimated and nope. It took this long. There was no warning of the long wait when placing the order, and there were many frustrated customers dining in and getting take out that were also waiting too long. I felt bad for the servers who had to bear the weight of the complaints. They checked on everyone's order multiple times and still no sign of our food. Then when I got my food, I took it to go and found out later that they got part of my order wrong. Too late for me to go all the way back and too hungry to chance the wait time again. 

3 stars - Dirty Sanchez Taco. Scrambled eggs with a fried poblano chile, guacamole, escabeche carrots and shredded cheese. Served with poblano sauce on a corn tortilla. The filling is generous for the taco and it's a big size taco. I think one would have filled me up nicely. This was like a breakfast taco, which I was looking for. Sometimes you just get that craving for breakfast for dinner. 

2 stars - The Independent Taco. Hand battered and fried portobello mushroom strips with refried black beans, roasted corn, escabeche carrots, quest fresco, cilantro, and avocado. Drizzled with ancho aioli on a corn tortilla. Too salty. The mushroom must have had a heavy handed sprinkling of salt before it got out in the taco. 

2 stars - Rice and beans. I found this to be salty too. The rice was a little undercooked to me too. 

Overall, the food is just not worth it for the long wait. If you're looking to try take out here, maybe call in your order and then use the wait time to do something productive before picking up your food.

I will admit the food is good... But the waitstaff is slow, doesn't know anything about their products, and if you send something back they get mad
I used to come here all the time, but the last time I was there, they literally flipped me off as I was leaving. I feel like I can't go back there because this guy was so rude to me, I've never been harassed or treated so rudely when all I want to do is eat and go

In the spirit of the 2016 Presidential election - I went to Torchy's and ordered the Democrat and the Republican tacos to help me shine some light on a possible decision (for good measure I also ordered the Bushfire taco).  The results.... well, the taco test proved inconclusive because the barbacoa featured in the democrat and the chorizo in republican both rocked -- but the shredded chicken Bushfire taco stole the show...  Torchy's has a great vibe - I've also been here for a bday dinner, for pre-softball grub and it's consistently good - the best part is trying all the tacos.. sooner or later you'll find one that you can't get enough of!

Torchy's has come to Denver!! 

I kept hearing from friends who had been to Torchy's in Texas and swear by it. Of course between that and the fact that it is a taco place, I had to go! I studied the menu before we arrived. Even after studying the whole menu, I couldn't decide on which tacos I wanted.  We arrived around 9:20 in the morning and boy am I glad that we did. The line became horrendous after we ordered.  Got there right in time! There were 3 of us and we decided to share the well known queso and chips. That queso is legit! Not only is it gooey queso, but it was filled with green chile! We ate every last bit before our tacos arrived.  I could have licked the bowl.

I ended up going with the Democrat (barbacoa taco), the chicken fajita taco and the fried avocado. My favorite was the fried avocado. I was told that these tacos were like street tacos, so I figured between the queso and the 3 tacos, I would be full.  LIARS! They are much larger than street tacos.  They are jam packed full. I could only eat a half of each of the tacos. I now know 2 are my max.

My words of advice: 1. If you like avocados get a fried avocado taco. 2. Get there early to avoid waiting in line forever. 3. Don't order too many, or be ready to eat a ton of leftovers. 4. Sit at the bar before ordering.  They take your taco and drink order and you can avoid the line. You're welcome!

The interior design and graphic design of the place is great: clean, modern, and inviting. 

We didn't wait more than ten minutes in line and were lucky to find a table being vacated as we were looking to sit - the place was packed (around 6pm on a Tuesday). The one girl at the cash register was the most miserable, unhappy cashier I've come across in recent memory - despite us being upbeat and cheerful towards her. She soured the initial experience. The other people working there seemed pleasant enough - perhaps she's just not suited to running the register. 

The portions were massive and the queso was good. I'd come back for the queso. The tacos were okay, but the Trailer Park was crazy (unpleasantly) salty. The salsas were okay, but lacked spice. My margarita was pretty good. 

It honestly didn't live up to the hype. Definitely not worth waiting 30+ minutes in line, in my opinion.

I loved Torchy's in Austin (both the original food truck and the fast food style restaurants) so I was happy to see Denver has one too!

The food:
Great tacos! Tons of variety - and the portions are huge. I haven't had a bad taco - breakfast or lunch/dinner varieties. Two tacos are definitely enough for me - and I always ask for corn tortillas instead of flour. If I had access to a Torchy's in my city, I'd be in trouble.

The experience:
There is ample free parking. You walk in, order at the counter, and they carry your food out to you. There was a bar though (with a bartender behind it) but I'm not sure if he can take food orders too.

The atmosphere:
This restaurant feels much cooler than any other Torchy's I've ever been to! It's beautiful, modern, large. And has a beautiful bar! There are also garage doors to create a patio-like space when the weather is warm.

I have loved Torchy's since the first time I tried it in Austin.  We were very excited to have the Denver location and it feels like they just think people will just a come even when the food sucks.  
We ate there this afternoon and with a very empty restaurant @ 3 PM on a Saturday, we waited over 40 minutes for our food... And when it arrived it was terrible.  The tortillas were so dry they were crumbling in our hands.. The salmon was dry and crusty and the temperature overall seemed like it had been sitting in the kitchen for 20 minutes waiting.

The restaurant temperature was set at about 50 degrees with ice cold air blowing, that it felt warmer on a fall day to be outside.  I asked if the air could be turned down and was told no.  

The only positive thing about this experience was the delicious Michelada- made by a very nice bartender Josh.  

If this were my first time at Torchys it would definitely be my last.. But I'm hoping this was an anomaly that can be corrected.

Finally made it to Torchys! I visited Torchys in Austin with the hubs earlier in 2015 after local folks had recommended it. I do remember saying that this kind of place would do well in Denver. I've driven by a few times now and there is always a long line out the door, but this afternoon, we lucked out! I stopped in with my daughter. I had the dirty sanchez and a baja shrimp taco. My daughter had the chicken strips kids meal with the fried avocado bites. The space is pretty neat. They have a bar as well and there were plenty of folks imbibing while we were there. My tacos were so dang good! The dirty sanchez (eggs, fried poblano, guacamole, escabeche carrots).. Yum, Yum, Yum.. So good! The baja shrimps tacos were light enough even though the shrimp were fried. They weren't overcooked and that's rare in shrimp tacos!

I'll be back!
Delicious taco selection. You have the option of adding whatever sauce you want to it. Be careful because the flavors can become very spicy. Side of corn is delicious and flavorful.

Definitely not just basic tacos. They are great for breakfast, lunch or dinner. My favorite is the barbacoa, which is made with cheek meat and hard to find in Denver. There are 2 full service bars, and if there's an open seat I recommend skipping the line and ordering food at the bar. There are a variety of hot sauces to choose from, they come on the side, so get s few and find your favorite.

Fun place with some really interesting taco fillings.  Love that everything is ordered ala carte - only a little hungry, then a single taco serves as a great snack, but add chips and salsa and another taco and you have a meal!  Prices are reasonable and there is parking.  The atmosphere is super casual, it can get a little loud, but overall a good place to grab a bite with friends.

Two tacos, queso and a margarita later and I'm stuffed to the gils! The queso is completely addicting. I ordered the republic (barbacoa)and brushfire (jerk chicken and mango). The republic was a tad bit fatty for my liking but I still devoured it. 

I was super impressed with the decor. It was completely beautiful. The perfect mix of modern/flashy/eclectic without overdoing it. I was a little skeptical - I thought torchys would be another hipster overpriced taco joint but I was pleasantly surprised. Tacos are affordable, delicious and I'm already planning my next visit! 

Pro tip: skip the line and order at the bar, grab a marg while you're at it!

Torchy's Tacos was amazing!! The selection was very diverse and every taco catered to a definitely type of meat, fish, or even if you're vegetarian. Make sure to get the green chile queso, it distracted me from my Tacos the entire time, SO YUMMY!

I must confess that we had no idea of the phenomena that is Torchys until we visited downtown Denver and our Denver friend brought us here! 

What can I say? Tacos are amazing! Kind of tough to screw them up unless you over cook the meat or over spice them. What I loved at Torchys were the veggie options! YES! FINALLY someone thinks of the grazers of the world. VEGETARIAN REFRIED BEANS! Thank you you wonderful Torchy chefs for thinking of this!

That being said, 2 tacos will fill you up. 3 and you are in a food coma. The guacamole is fresh to death and the corn was off the charts buttttt a too much for one person to consume. 

Do I even need to say the selection of beer is awesome as well? This is Denver after all. 

Pro-tips: this place is uber popular so expect to wait BUT, seats at the bar get you full service so keep an eye out!

Cons: parking. Blah. Street, meters, and tow away zones. Be prepared to search.
My favorite breakfast spot in Denver! I always try to make time to stop by for breakfast tacos. My only complaint is the coffee. It's usually pretty watered down.

The tacos come out cold or luke warm. They aren't very flavorful. I've come here three times and was disappointed every time. I came in for lunch one day and ended up leaving because the bar tender never came over to give me a menu. 

It's like a fancy wanna be Moontower Tacos... I miss that place. I'd rather go to Tacos Junior.

We came in around 8 pm on a Saturday night- what a crowd! The line extended past the outside walls. After waiting about 30 minutes, we finally made it inside to order our food.

I've heard lots of rave reviews about Torchy's, mostly from friends who enjoyed it in Texas. My husband and I each ordered two tacos, and we were pleased by the portions. I'd say for the price you pay, the value and taste definitely outweighs other fast-casual Mexican. 

Be sure to try their signature green chile queso!

I've seen it, driven by it and always a huge line. The hype had gotten to me, so I finally broke down and went on day when the line was reasonable. The selection is pretty good, and the naming of the tacos was cute. I got a Pork Green Chile and a 'democrat' taco. Both descriptions sounded good, but they were just so-so. The 'democrat' was filled with beef, and it was a little dry and over cooked. Stringy is what I would say. The Pork Green Chile was moist and tasty, but I didn't really get the green chile flavor. Again, so-so.

The drink policy there is weird. You can't order a drink if you one in front of you. If you don't like what you ordered, you can't order another one until you either finish, bring it back or dump it. There are many times when I order a beer, and it's not that good, but after a different beer, the first one tastes better. I can't explain it but if you've ever had a 'flight' of beer, and didn't like one, but came back to it later and it tasted better, you know what I mean.

All in all, it's an OK place, but I don't think the hype delivered the result I was expecting.

Alright with all the buzz around town about Torchy's I had to give it a try myself. Being a fan of Moontown I was sad to see it go, but I heard Torchy's was very similar. It definitely is, but more packed. I'm not sure why there is a line out the door. Don't get me wrong the tacos are good, but they aren't great. They lack spice and flavor like an authentic taco would have. I get that these are non-traditional tacos, but the salsas were not hot and lacked flavor. 

We tried the Barbacoa which was filled to the brim with meat, the Pork Carnitas which was less full, but essentially the same taco, the "trashy" taco, and a Veggie with the fried mushrooms. I think the street corn was the best item we had, gave me a fond reminder of Moontower * sigh * 

The atmosphere is one of a Chipotle "slow fast food" which is great if your looking for a fast meal, even though it likely won't be that fast because of the lines. Once the hype slows down I think this will be more of a quick fix for you taco lovers. Until then, I don't think its exactly worth the wait. Check out Pinche's on Colfax- a little more authentic and sit down. 

I'll give it another try once the lines die down.

I finally made it into Torchy's for a business lunch today after hearing all my friends rave about their tacos, and demand that I try their queso, or "I shall not pass". My business associate and I met there early, knowing how crazy busy this place gets, and one of us even scored a parking space in their lot (yessss!).

We waited in a short line, which was fine, because we had time to peruse the menu. I had the Green Chile Pork and the Fried Avocado tacos. The pork was really yummy!! Will probably pass on the fried avocado one next time, and try something different next time. My business associate had a Republican, a Crossroads, and a Brushfire, and she enjoyed them all. She was able to get them all on corn tortillas instead of flour to adapt to her gluten-free diet, which was really great! We also ordered the queso and some chips and salsa. The chips could be better (perhaps I'm wrong, but I believe they're pre-made out of a bag and I love me some homemade chips), but the queso is pretty tasty. The salsa? Meh. Not a lot of flavor and not much spice. 

The service here is really amazing. Everyone is super friendly and despite them being really busy by the time we sat down and got our food, the manager still found time to come around and say hello and check in, as did another higher-up. They also had a couple of other employees helping bus tables, which was nice. Overall, it was a very pleasant visit, and I'll definitely be back!

Torch's Tacos sticks out so much on Broadway that it can't be ignored.  The bright red sign, the hip architecture, and bright lettering is almost Vegas-like on the street.

Torchys Tacos to Austin is what I imagine that Illegal Pete's is to Colorado, which is to say that it's kind of a big deal.

But I encourage you to wait at least a few weeks.

I got lucky, and was able to get inside on the line.  To the far back, but I figured it would be about as long as Illegal Pete's/Qdoba/Chipotle.  No, took about fifteen minutes to get to the front, and an additional fifteen to get my tacos.  When I left, the line was out the door, and about twenty people deeper.  Crazy.

The tacos are very good.  Slightly bigger than a street taco, but very flavorful.  If you want to seem like a Torchys elitist, look up the SECRET MENU.  I asked the cashier, and she's well aware of it too.  

Good stuff, but do not wait half an hour guys.  With a few more locations opening up this year, it'll be good.

I was walking by 8:30 on a Friday night and the line was really long, so I figured it must be good. I ordered the fried avocado on a corn tortilla and a trashy trailer park on flour. They were delicious. The soft, warm avocado was amazing. The trashy trailer park taco was everything I'd hoped it to be from the many reviews I read about it. The menu had several more offerings that caught my eye, so I hope to return to try them.

The only negative point was the cashier. I paid in cash and handed her a large bill and said I've got the change. I got the change out of my pocket and handed it to her, and she said she'd entered it as a whole dollar amount and she handed me back my coins. She started to count out the change and I explained to her that I'll just give her all the change in exchange for a one dollar bill. She then closed the drawer and said "sorry, I just closed the drawer." I feel sorry for the poor girl when life hands her something more complicated than 28 cents to deal with.

American Style Tacos!

Chose the two top sellers and they were delicious (can't remember the names). Tip: sit at the bar if there is a spot and you can order food there as well since the line is always out the door.

Came with a friend before at their grand opening, and thought their tacos were really good! Even worth their high price. Came back yesterday for an order to go. 
Six tacos at $27.00. Ouch. The salsa was amazing that they included with them (cilantro heavy, yum!), but the tacos themselves were disappointing for the money. That might've been because we didn't eat them for 20 minutes until we arrived at our destination. But overall I still am sad I spent $30 on just tacos. 
Wish they offered meal deals or something.

5 stars for the queso. 4 stars for the tacos. 

Their queso may be life-changing. Or maybe it's just the ideal hangover cure. Either way, I would drink it. 

The tacos are super tasty. Lots of varieties to choose from. Are they the best tacos I've ever had in my whole life? No (hence the 4 stars) but they are for sure solid.

I don't say this often, but this place is honestly underrated. If you are looking for tacos in Denver then your options are moderately limited. Not many places are solely committed to tacos. When you order tacos in Denver you often order it from an establishment that doesn't specialize in the food.

Torchys specializes in tacos, and you can tell. You can tell based on the variety and the taste. If you are a taco lover, than give this place a try.

I've been to Torchy's three times now. Three different days of the week. Three different times of day. AND. THERE. IS. ALWAYS. A. LINE.

It's like Denver's never seen tacos before...geez.

Well to be fair, Torchy's makes a damn fine taco. I remember them from my days in Austin, where Torchy's was among the many (though certainly not the best) Texas-style taco joints. I preferred Las Manitas, Porfirio's or Juan in a Million. But Torchy's was good for late-night after-bar tacos or a nice morning breakfast tacos (which is far superior to Denver's ubiquitous breakfast burritos in my opinion).

Torchy's rarely had a very long line and was always a pretty quick meal.

For some reason it's always a long line here. It was so long last time that I nearly missed my lunch hours standing in line.

But again damn if that taco ain't delicious. I especially like their breakfast tacos...everthing from the simple bacon, egg and cheese to the migas. They have a great migas, served with avocado, tomatillo sauce and corn tortilla crunchiness. I would love it if they also had a red-chile sauce migas, but the tomatillo is distinctly tart and wonderful in combination with the rest of the ingredients.

The rest of the tacos are also great...love the Dirty Sanchez, the Baja Shrimp, the Democrat. Though I have to say some of the "BBQ" style tacos I don't care for as much.

Service for me at this place has been a bit spotty. I've gotten the wrong taco two of my three visits. And the way they do the service here, makes it kind of complicated/awkward to get it fixed, though to their credit they did it each time

And maybe I am impatient, but I don't care to wait in line for tacos. But sometimes when the taco craving hits, you simply must.

Torchys replaced what used to be Arby's, giving a new look on the block of 11th and broadway. Parking here can be difficult depending on how busy the place is. My friend and I came here around 4:30p and it was still a decent crowd in here.

You go up to the counter to order before seating yourself. Maybe it's because this place gets busy, the cashier seemed a bit impatient at my indecisiveness when ordering. My friend and I ended up sharing a queso dip with chorizo & chips and I ordered a Mr. Orange taco. Each taco ranges from 3-5 dollars depending on what you get. 

The chips and dip came out pretty quickly after we sat down, but our tacos came out about 20 minutes later after (we only ordered one each). Overall the food is decent, but the service can definitely use some improvement.

At first I didn't buy into the hype. However, after eating at Torchy's, since our brunch plans fell through, I must say that I bought the hype. Hook, line and sinker! 

Right after we entered Torchy's, the line went out the door! That's how popular this place is. It took a little while to get to the counter, since the place was packed, but as soon as we got there, the server was friendly and quick to get our orders. 

I ordered the Queso and Chips (which were amazing), a Democrat taco (shredded Barbacoa), a Brushfire taco (Jamaican Jerk chicken), and a Grande Burrito (What can I say? Our Brunch plans got canceled and I was starving!). My wife ordered the Mr. Pink (seared ahi-tuna), and the Baja Shrimp tacos. Needless to say, all of the tacos were superb! 

They also have a full service bar, where you can sit and order food, without having to stand in line. Which works great if you don't have kids, and need a little hair of the dog to go along with your tacos! The Bloody Mary I had was great and it only cost $3! 

This is a great place for a quick meal, as well as a Sunday Brunch with the family. Torchy's is opening locations in Greenwood Village and Stapleton, which means that I can get my taco cravings during the week!

I typically hold "trendy" restaurants to a higher standard than normal because cynically I think people just like feeling hip, but don't necessarily know what good food is supposed to be. 

Torchy's, for me, severely underperformed. I ordered the Democrat, in which the meat was severely dry and overcooked. I can't even remember the other taco that I ordered. There really isn't anything special here, besides the large amount of options. I've had plenty of better street tacos at dumpy little hole in the walls.  

If you like loud trendy restaurants for a meal under $15, then maybe this is your place. I'll stick with others.

Average at best or on par with Taco Bell. Long wait for our food and when it did arrive , it was incomplete , dry, bland 
and COLD!!!!!! Tables were very dirty and the place seemed understaffed. Bartenders have more important things to do than tend to the needs of the ones paying their bills...ie THE CUSTOMER.  Save your money and go to 
 PInche Tacos. Service is only slightly better, but the food is way better and HOT.  One extra star because the girl who took our order was very nice. Someone should take a torch to Torchys , because it is way below average and way overrated.

Awesomely delicious. Hillbilly on the Trailer Park was....ridiculous....amazing. Mr. Pink was good too.

Wonderful tacos!

Oh, how I am so glad Torchy's is in Denver!! They've been here less than a year and now have several locations and I can see why!! I have been here countless times and always satisfied. 
Every time I come, I try to order something different, working my way down the menu. The taco of the month is usually my favorite, but you seriously cannot go wrong with any of them. My personal favorite is the trailer park, the fried chicken is amazing. 
The Broadway location always had a line out the door and for good reasons, but it goes fast. I try and sit at the bar when I come, usually for brunch and able to always grab a seat. There is ample seating and I love the bar in the middle that wraps around the middle. 
The staff is very attentive, the food comes out quick and the drinks are on point. The bloody mary has the perfect amount of spice and always gives a good buzz. One is plenty and after two, you're set!

I wasn't too impressed upon my first couple visits. As another reviewer mentioned, the potatoes in the breakfast tacos aren't the best--they can be undercooked, which is a cardinal sin when it comes to potatoes. I've also had a couple tacos where the potatoes were very gritty, which was gross. However, I've been back more and now I love it! I now get the Migas or Dirty Sanchez, and they are great. The queso is excellent (though I wish they offered a small side of it, as a full order is huge and I'd love to order a small queso with my taco). And the refried beans are my favorite beans around. Some reviews state that it's way overpriced--really? I don't get any tacos with meat, but the veggie ones are around $3.50 and are huge, so if I get two it's plenty, and that's only $7 for a meal!

My coworker from Austin had been talking about this place for months. So, my expectations were pretty high. I got the pink taco or whatever it's called. The one with tuna. And some chips and queso. The queso was fine, I'm a bad judge on queso because...I don't really like queso...but I've heard they have some of the best so I had to try it. 

The taco was pretty disappointing. Now, know that I got carryout....so that possibly had something to do with it. It was just kind of bland and the tortilla was not good. It was also really sloppily packaged and falling apart when I opened it. I even went during a time when they weren't busy, thinking that might help. 

I don't know, I was just pretty disappointed. There wasn't anything terribly wrong, the service was good and the environment was totally fine. For the price and the wait, I don't think I'll go back though.

This place is the jam!! To-die-for tacos, Vegetarian options: Dr. Sanchez and the Fried Avocado. Outrageously delicious queso complete with spices, avocado, feta, and a dash of hot sauce. Austin TX based Co. I am so happy they've arrived in Colorado. A great place to hang out have drinks too!

I love the queso and the corn here. The tacos are all decent, and HUGE. Being from Texas, they've certainly embraced the everything is bigger stance.  

It sucks that there's a HUGE line every single time. I would order to go and then just eat in.

I tried the Baja, chicken fajita, beef fajita, the independence, the bushfire, and the democrat. My favorite ones were the Baja and the independence with the sauce and the way the shrimp and mushrooms were seasoned. Both the chicken and beef fajita was tender and tasty, but the democrat was really dry and my least favorite of all the ones I've tried.

The food is great, I can't deny that... But I've been there multiple times and had the waitstaff and management be rude, frazzled, and all around unpleasant. It's a restaurant. Learn how to handle a busy crowd.

After all the hype I experienced before going to Torchys I was expecting some great tacos. They were just okay. I tried the Baja Shrimp, and the shrimp were just so overcooked they were difficult to eat. I also tried the Trailer Park and got it trashy as recommended, except I don't think there was any queso? It was basically a generic chicken strip with cheese on it, not really the fried chicken queso experience I was expecting.

The lines here are way too long to justify eating the subpar tacos.

Living a few blocks from Torchys means that you'll be well-acquainted with the line. And what a great line it will be! Clearly, Mexico has financed this line. Nice work, Torchys, for taking it and making it your own.

That said, I only dared to wait in this line once, and this review is the tale of that complex journey. Rating this establishment isn't easy. Yes, the food is good. And if that were the only criterion, that'd make it an easy assessment. But what about the menu, sold-out tacos, slow service, prices and that abominable line? The food is good, but it's not without flaw. Heavy ingredients seem to be paired with even more calorically dense ingredients. Yes, you can get a bright-tasting citrusy taco, but who the hell wants to order a heart-clogger? I'm sure the demand is there, but I don't view restaurants that serve novelty food through the same lens.

When it comes down to it, though, the tacos buoyed my review of this place. There's a lot to dislike about this place, but the tacos aren't one of them. Hopefully, once the hype dies down, Torchys will be able to keep the momentum that's clearly been generated by their food (and not anything else, because really there isn't much else they're able to offer diners).

Go to Torchys. Try the tacos.

Came here with a friend after hearing it was a new taco "hot spot"... Have to say, I was not impressed (there are a lot of way better taco joints in Denver).

I'm writing this review a few weeks after my visit, and honestly, the food was so  unmemorable, that I don't even remember what we ordered... One was a tuna taco and I think the other was called "the democrat" (I should have known based on the name alone that I wouldn't like it). My friend had two tacos also, and one of them had something so spicy on it, that when he bit into it he started turning red and I thought for a moment he was choking! (Bartender gave him no warning that the taco was unbearably hot when he ordered it)

My friend and I sat at the bar, which if you do checkout Torchy's, is definitely the "way to go" because then you can by-pass the huge line at the front and just place your food order directly with the bartender.

The tacos here are big... So if you want quantity over quality, this may be the right place for you.

Overall, there are so many other good taco places in Denver, so I will not be going back to Torchy's

We were looking for a taco Tuesday spot and came across this place. They do not have any taco Tuesday specials, but we decided to sit at the bar and have a few beers and try them anyway. 

They had a few beers on special $2 Lone Star bottles and Modelo cans. We started off with their queso and guacamole. The guac was super yummy, nice and fresh & light - I specifically remember the cilantro in it. The queso was ok, I've had better. Probably won't re order it if/when I return. 

They have quite a selection of tacos, ranging from about $2-$5 per taco. I had the trailer park taco - trashy style. It was delish! 

Sitting at the bar was a nice alternative to waiting in the never ending line they always seem to have when I drive by! Which, I guess is a pretty solid indicator that their food is worth the wait!

My husband and I came here because a local recommended it saying it's the best tacos in the area. We both love Mexican food, so we had high expectations. Unfortunately,  we were highly disappointed. 

The restaurant was packed when we got there,  with the line out the door so we figured it must be good. We both ordered two tacos and one burrito to go for later. I also got a margarita. The tacos were average. They messed up my husband's order, putting the wrong sauce on. They told us the sauce was not hot, but it was extremely hot! The margarita was good, but that's it. We ate the burritos later that day, and they were horrible. We only got a couple bites in and couldn't eat any more.

Queso queso queso queso.

You don't think queso can change your life? Me either til I got some here. GO GET IT. NOW.

There's still a big hype for this place. Understandable since this place lives up to the hype. There are still lines out the door at nearly all times of the day. Try to pony up to the bar. If not camp out and wait for a spot to open. It usually will.

The tacos I've eaten so far have been superb..well almost. I can do without the brushfire because jamaican jerk doesn't have a place inside a taco. But the green chile pork/trailer park tacos are ridic. And get em' trashy cuz well queso on everything is always a good choice.

Drinks could be stronger tho......

Love the food, the folks who bring it out are stellar. Ordering from the counter has its ups and downs, though. If you want/need anything else then you need to get back up and in line to grab it. Otherwise I will return again and again.

All the tacos have been fabulous. The Democrat and Independent, the Trailer Park ( I think that's the name) was great yet I'm unsure if the "Trashy" portion of extra cheese is necessary. I'd prefer it melted. The Queso is to die for.

Well this was my first time in Denver and we were staying at a nearby hotel. What so I see is a brand new Torchys...now I'm all about trying local places but I had to see how this Austin chain would be all the way up in Denver. Final verdict..amazing! Being the new thing in town I hear the line can get very long. We came at around 10ish on a Friday night and there wasn't a line. We ordered at the counter and sat at the bar. I didn't know this but you could have ordered at the bar..so something to think of when there is a line. 

Now the only Torchys I've been to was the one near UT Austin and it's a small honestly near dive taco shop. This one in Denver is amazingly beautiful...super big and nice. Plus there is a huge bar!

I can't remember all the tacos we had but we tried their shrimp special and the trailer trash. Drinks were really good and this turned out to be a great night. 

It was so good that on our way to the airport the next day we stopped for so,e breakfast tacos..again got there around 10ish in the morning on a Saturday with no line. 

Denver your lucky to get a Torchys. I'm hoping they find their way to Phoenix here soon!

Based on all the hype surrounding this place, I thought I'd be blown away.  The chips and queso were tasty, but anything cheese related is arguably hard to fumble.  Ordered the Green Chili Pork taco, the Republican taco, and the Beef Fajita taco.  The corn tortillas were dry and overly delicate and the contents of each of the tacos was average at best.  

While I'm certainly not one to complain about getting too much food, the size of the tacos made them hard to manage. Not feeling like the corn tortillas were worth the calories or the effort, I resigned myself to eating the inside contents with a fork.  

I will say that the service was decent.  We sat at the bar and the place was packed.  However, in the future I'd opt for Machete or Los Chingones when I'm in the market for some bomb a** tacos.  I feel their creations are more unique, tasty, and manageable.

Let me start by saying that I LOVE, LOVE, LOVE Torchy's in Austin, and was thrilled when I heard there was was one opening here in Denver.  

Of course with just one location of deliciousness, it is always busy (line out the door busy)...so that's not fun, but expected.  Grabbing seats in the bar is key...but of course everyone has the same idea.

I do have to say that the tacos haven't been as amazing as our experiences in Austin (either a bit dry, or a bit too salty), and I was a bit disappointed that the queso here doesn't come with chorizo like it does in Austin.  I do have faith things will improve once all the kinks are worked out..and we'll keep coming back.

So.. .they have some bugs to work out, but the good news is that the tacos, and especially the queso, are very very good! 

I have now been twice since opening. The last time I went, it took us about an hour to get our food, which is obviously less than ideal, but I also know that they are new, and demand is insane. I just hope that it improves. 

Recocmendation: get the fried avocado taco, and make any taco 'trashy' and get their delicious queso on top. SO good!

I mean I know it's Torchy's but a 45 minute wait? Really? Really Denver? What is with you having a line for every chain that comes to Denver? End Rant.

I had tried to go to Torchy's a couple times before I finally got to order some food. I went at 9:00 am on a Sunday and the parking lot was still full and this place was poppin. All I wanted was some queso. That queso was the bomb. I am glad I ordered a fried avocado taco too. I figured since it'll take me a few months to get back in and have a taco again. The building itself is beautiful. Service is good. I really want to try it when the hype dies down so that I can really enjoy my time there. I'm glad they are opening more locations in Denver so this one can hopefully die down a bit.

Yay Torchy's! Your guacamole is the best I've had in quite some time! I think the secret is the hint of lime.

Your tacos rock(o)! Many combos from which to choose, I'm not sure that there is a way to lose.

Salsa so flavorful and with a bit of spice. Eating their salsa with chips is very nice!

Great ambiance and a fun vibe too! Going to Torchy's will cure your blues.

Still one star. I'd actually take one away had I given them any. We decided to try picking the tacos up because we miss Moontower. I don't care if they borrowed ideas from Torchys, because they did them better and the ideas were pretty much just 'tacos'.

Last time I had a horrendous experience with decent tacos and excellent queso. This time, we picked up the order, still pretty miserable and loud inside but I didn't have to be there as long. We got a democrat and it was dry and flavorless, both kinds of fish tacos completely fell apart and had to be eaten with a fork ('mediocre' she says), and the fourth was something with fried chicken, but it was ice cold. Disgusting.

If you don't want to make tacos then don't be a taco place. Just be a margarita place. Those exist, you know? They're called bars. Think of this as a loud bar filled with Texans and lousy tacos.

On a whim and with some good reviews from friends, my wife and I stopped in in a Wednesday afternoon around 3:30. The restaurant was moderately packed. We ordered our food and it was delivered relatively quickly. The iced tea is fresh and they have a great choice of pure cane sodas to drink. We got an order of chips and guacamole, very fresh and tasty with a hint of cilantro. Our tacos were delicious. The tortillas tasted freshly made (a major win). The salsas that came with our tacos were great and we got a couple others to try--terrific!!!  I overheard a manager talk to a potential employee about standing room only Friday through Sunday. I'm not sure if that's good or bad seeing that most people will want to sit to eat tacos (great for business, but they might want to increase the size of their restaurant to accommodate the crowds). All in all, excellent food!!!  We will be back soon.
Pretty good tacos. They did put cheese on top when I asked for none, however they were still pretty tasty. Nice variety. Good ambiance. Fun Sunday afternoon with friends!!
Glad to have another Mexican option in DTC.  I love the queso!  Tacos are pretty good.  Its pretty crowded at lunch so sometimes that deters me, but great service.
So so... The bartender was to occupied talking with friends to get the order right... The food was decent but I've had better at wahoos

Moved here from LA two years ago and these were the best tacos I have had in Denver so far! Excellent taste, spice, and flavor combinations. We will definitely be back.

We took to go so I can't comment on the in house service

Some of the tacos are pretty amazing (Trailer Park, Democrat, Republican and Brushfire)

All the breakfast taco's I've had have been very underwhelming and basically all egg. I wish they would put more steak/brisket on them.

Ace of Spades from the secret menu was one of the worst things i've ever eaten. Sounded delicious but something was just off about it. The bartender told me after it a lot of other people didn't like it as well. Wish I would have known that before I ordered.

Overall definetly worth the hype. Just try a bunch of things till you know what you like there.

Moved here from Texas last summer and after trying many different "taco joints" it was hard to accept the realization that Denver does not offer breakfast tacos anywhere (not burritos, there is a difference). Moontower wasn't my favorite but maybe I am bias because I had the originals from torchy's before trying Moontower. So needless to say I have been anticipating the opening of torchy's for quite some time.

I had it today and was very pleased that they offered the same tacos and everything tasted the same!!! I know I will get ridiculed for this in Denver but here it goes...I'm happiest about the fact that they don't want to drown everything on the menu in green chili!!!

Breakfast Recommendations:
Sausage, egg and cheese.
Bean, cheese and bacon.
Flour tortillas only

Lunch/Dinner Recommendations:
Strawberry/Mango Swirl Margarita (only $4)
Baja shrimp
Green Chile Pulled Pork
Beef or Chicken fajita
Street corn is a must (just order it and thank me later)

A co-worker told me today that this was the taco sensation that has swooped into Denver.  Naturally, I went.  Today.  I had no idea what I was getting myself into which was both good and bad.  Bad because I did not give myself nearly enough time to stand in line and get back in a reasonable amount of time.  Good because the tacos were a delicious medley of flavors dancing on my tongue.

My first toe dip into their menu was the fried avocado taco and the fried mushroom taco.  I love the idea of a mushroom taco and can't say that I have ever seen that before.  As such that was my preferred taco of the two.  I would have preferred a corn tortilla for both but will ask for that next time.

What I should have got was the smoked brisket taco with jalepenos.  I cannot remember the name but I tried a sample of the meat from a co-workers taco and wow.  So good.

What to say about this place...
